Welcome to bgg-cohomology’s documentation!¶

  • Installation
  • BGGComplex

Implement the BGG complex

Uses compute_maps.py and compute_signs.py to obtain the maps with associated signs of the BGG complex. To use the BGG complex to compute cohomology we can use fast_module.

class bggcomplex.BGGComplex(root_system, pickle_directory=None)[source]¶

A class encoding all the things we need of the BGG complex

compute_maps(root, column=None, check=False, pbar=None)[source]¶

For the given weight, compute the maps of the BGG complex

compute_signs(force_recompute=False)[source]¶

Computes signs for all the edges so that the product of signs around any admissible cycle is -1. Returns a dictionary with the edges as keys and the signs as values.

display_maps(mu)[source]¶

Displays all the maps of the BGG complex for a given mu, in appropriate order. mu is assumed to be a tuple encoding it as a linear combination of weights.

display_pbw(f, notebook=True)[source]¶

Typesets an element of PBW of the universal enveloping algebra with LaTeX. Options: notebook = True; uses IPython display with math if True, otherwise just returns the LaTeX code.

dot_action(reflection, weight)[source]¶

Compute the dot action of a reflection on a weight. The reflection should be an element of the Weyl group self.W and the weight should be given as a tuple encoding it as a linear combination of simple roots.

find_cycles()[source]¶

Find all the admitted cycles in the BGG graph. An admitted cycle consists of two paths a->b->c and a->b’->c, where the word length increases by 1 each step. The cycles are returned as tuples (a,b,c,b’,a).

is_dot_regular(mu)[source]¶

Check if a weight is dot-regular by checking that it has trivial stabilizer

plot_graph()[source]¶

Create a pretty plot of the BGG graph. Each word length is encoded by a different color. Usage: _.plot_graph().plot()

weight_to_alpha_sum(weight)[source]¶

Express a weight in the lattice as a linear combination of alpha[i]’s. These objects form the keys for elements of the Lie algebra, and for factors in the universal enveloping algebra.
